thread.title: Indian Hotels Share Price: Indian Hotels shares 2.77% as Sensex rises - The Economic Times
thread.title_full: Indian Hotels Share Price: Indian Hotels shares 2.77% as Sensex rises - The Economic Times

title: Indian Hotels Share Price: Indian Hotels shares 2.77% as Sensex rises - The Economic Times
text: Shares of Indian Hotels Company Ltd. 2.77 per cent to Rs 799.40 in Friday's session as of 12:37PM (IST) even as the equity benchmark Sensex traded 25.75 points at 77645.96. Earlier in the day, the stock witnessed a gap up start to the session. The stock quoted a 52-week high price of Rs 894.15 and a 52-week low of Rs 450.55 on NSE. Around 22123 shares changed hands on the counter till 12:37PM (IST). The stock opened at Rs 822.80 and has touched an intraday high and low of Rs 823.05 and Rs 799.40 during the session so far. The counter quoted a price-to-earnings (PE) ratio of 68.14, earnings per share (EPS) of Rs 11.75 and price to book value (PB) of 8.90, while the return on equity (ROE) stood at Rs 13.31. Promoter/ FII Holding The promoters held 38.12 per cent stake in the company as of January 10, while FII and MF ownerships stood at 27.44 per cent and 13.89 per cent, respectively. Key Financials With a market capitalisation of Rs 113981.34 crore, the company operates in the Hotels & Resorts industry. For the quarter ended 30-Sep-2024, the company reported consolidated sales of Rs 1890.2200 crore, 18.41 per cent from the previous quarter?s Rs 1596.2700 crore and 27.64 per cent from the same quarter a year ago. The company reported net of Rs 554.58 crore for the latest quarter, 232.24 per cent from the corresponding quarter last year. Technical Indicators The relative strength index (RSI) of the stock stands at 37.43. The RSI oscillates between zero and 100. Traditionally, it is considered overbought condition when the RSI value is above 70 and oversold condition when it is below 30. Analysts say the RSI indicator should not be seen in isolation, as it may not be sufficient to take a trading call, just the way a fundamental analyst cannot give a buy or sell recommendation using a single valuation ratio.
